article.body: Mortgage rates continue to hover near their all-time low. And the Federal Reserveâs approach to the economic recovery might keep them lower for longer. The 30-year fixed-rate mortgage average 3.21% for the week ending June 11, up three basis points from a week earlier, Freddie Mac FMCC, +0.52% Â reported Thursday. Meanwhile, the 15-year fixed-rate mortgage and the 5-year Treasury-indexed hybrid adjustable rate mortgage were both unchanged from last week at 2.62% and 3.1% respectively. Mortgage rates hit a fresh record low at the end of May, when the 30-year rate dropped to 3.15%. It was the third time that rates hit an all-time low this year. The Fed controls short-term interest rates, so the policy wonât directly impact mortgage rates. Instead, mortgage rates roughly track the direction of long-term bond yields, including the 10-year Treasury note TMUBMUSD10Y, 0.777% Â . The yield on the 10-year note initially fell in response to the Fedâs announcement. More notably for the mortgage market, Powell also said the Fed will continue buying mortgage-backed securities âat least at the current pace.â That will continue to pump liquidity into the mortgage market, which lenders will use to continue to offer low rates to attract borrowers. âWith no end in sight for this Fed policy, itâs likely that mortgage rates are poised to remain low for a while,â Speakman said.
